data.title: 1. Armee – Axis History
data.text:
Published: 25 March 2011

The 1. Armee was formed on 26 August 1939 in Wehrkreis XII. After taking part in the invasion of France in 1940, the 1. Armee remained there on occupation duty guarding the Atlantic coast from the Loire River to the Spanish border. It provided forces for Operation “Anton”, the occupation of Vichy France in November 1942 together with Armeegruppe Felber. After retreating through France in August-September 1944, the 1. Armee fought a protracted defensive battle in Lorraine. It took part in Operation “Nordwind,” the failed offensive in Alsace in December 1944-January 1945, and, after retreating from the Saar-Palatinate, fell back beyond the Rhine River. Forced back into Bavaria, it surrendered there to U.S. forces on 8 May 1945.

Commanders

Generalfeldmarschall Erwin von Witzleben (26 Aug 1939 – 25 Oct 1940)

Generaloberst Johannes Blaskowitz (25 Oct 1940 – 10 May 1944)

General der Panzertruppe Joachim Lemelsen (10 May 1944 – 2 June 1944)

General der Infanterie Kurt von der Chevallerie (2 June 1944 – 5 Sep 1944)

General der Panzertruppe Otto von Knobelsdorff (5 Sep 1944 – 30 Nov 1944)

General der Infanterie Hans von Obstfelder (30 Nov 1944 – 28 Feb 1945)

General der Infanterie Hermann Foertsch (28 Feb 1945 – 6 May 1945) (POW)

General der Kavallerie Rudolf Koch-Erpach (6 May 1945 – 8 May 1945)

Chiefs of Staff

Generalmajor Friedrich Mieth (26 Aug 1939 – 5 Feb 1940)

Generalmajor Carl Hilpert (5 Feb 1940 – 25 Oct 1940)

Generalmajor Edgar Röhricht (25 Oct 1940 – 16 June 1942)

Generalmajor Anton-Reichard Freiherr von Mauchenheim genannt Bechtolsheim (16 June 1942 – 1 Aug 1943)

Oberst Gerhard Feyerabend (1 Aug 1943 – 10 Sep 1944)

Oberst Willi Mantey (10 Sep 1944 – 7 Dec 1944)

Oberst Walter Reinhard (7 Dec 1944 – 20 Feb 1945)

Generalmajor Wolf Rüdiger Hauser (20 Feb 1945 – 8 May 1945)

Operations Officers (Ia)

Oberst Gustav Harteneck (26 Aug 1939 – 7 Nov 1940)

Oberst Kurt Adam (10 Nov 1940 – 30 Sep 1941)

Oberst Lothar Schäfer (30 Sep 1941 – 25 Nov 1942)

Oberstleutnant Hans Gronemann-Schoenborn (25 Nov 1942 – Dec 1942)

Oberst Markert (Dec 1942 – Apr 1943)

Major Walter Carganico (Apr 1943 – Nov 1943)

Oberst Albert Emmerich (15 Nov 1943 – 8 May 1945)

Area of operations

Western front (Aug 1939 – May 1945)

Holders of high awards

Holders of the German Cross in Silver (2)

– Blaskowitz, Johannes, 30.10.1943, Generaloberst, OB 1. Armee

– Müller, Immo, 30.10.1943, Oberst, Armee-Nachrichtenführer AOK 1

Holders of the Knight’s Cross (1)

– Witzleben von, Erwin 24.06.1940 Generaloberst OB 1. Armee

Holders of high awards (Armee-Truppen)

Holders of the German Cross in Gold (1)

– Kühn, Gottfried, 07.01.1945, Rittmeister d.R., Sturm-Btl. AOK 1

Notable members

Johannes Blaskowitz (Generaloberst who as Oberbefehlshaber Ost sent an official memorandum to Hitler complaining about atrocities of the SS-Totenkopfverbände in Poland 1939)

Erwin von Witzleben (Active in the resistance against Hitler and executed after the failure of the July 20 Plot)

Georg Tessin – Verbände und Truppen der deutschen Wehrmacht 1933-1945
